casebody.data:
M’Neill’s Case. The prisoner had, together with two other person i, been convicted of a conspiracy at the last Oyer and Terminer for the city and county of New York, but 'had not appeared on his recognizance in time to receive sentence: he after-wards came in, and was now brought up, on his own petition, to have judgment pronounced; but the xvccord [*73] of -'the conviction not being made up and brought into court, the bench said they had nothing before them on which to' proceed; and, therefore, adm tted him to bail.

The court will not pronounce judgment on » prisoner convicted a Oyer anj Terminer of a conspiracy, if the record of his conviction le ot before them, but will admit to bail.
